subject: Dynamically creating a test case for an XML document
msgSnippet: Hello, I have several files on disk which each represent an XML request to our system.  I d like to test that our system is processing each of these correctly
messageBody:
Hello,
I have several files on disk which each represent an XML request to
our system. I'd like to test that our system is processing each of
these correctly (and hopefully dilineate each test seperately in the
results). Each request file also has an expected error code, for
ensuring the server processed the request as expected. So I need to
read each of these files in, send them to the server for processing,
and then test that their return code is what was expected. In my
elementary understanding of JUnit, I can do this one of two ways:

1. Create a "test" method for each file on the filesystem. Each
method would call through to a protected which method which actually
performs the test. Advantage: I get independent results for each
file on the system. Disadvantage: I'd need to add a new "test"
method each time a new request file is added.

2. Create a single "test" method which iterates through the set of
files, processing each. Advantage: we could have a variable amount of
test requests without changing code. Disadvantage: the set of
requests is treated as one unit(one fails, they all show up as a
failure).

Is there a way to "parameterize" this process? Perhaps by allowing
multiple successes/failures in a single "test" method, or somehow
allowing "test" methods that take paramters, that are somehow
dilineated in the results?

No good recommendations, just naive questions... sorry.

Thanks for any help,
Adam
